subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] new box idea
author: Snowfire Lioness
full_text:
----------MB_8CDA713B4C1FC48_C18_137F4_Webmail-m112.sysops.aol.com
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"

 A fan might work with this type of thing too, but it might make too much n=
oise. I did get some fairly good files using a fan one hot summer, with the=
 box, but the sound from the fan reached the mic, and it sounds like they a=
re out in a wind storm, but it did make them a bit louder. sf

 



-----Or=
iginal Message-----
From: johniestring <johniestring@...>
To: E=
VP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wed, Mar 2, 2011 1:42 am
Subject: [EVP-ITC] ne=
w box idea

          =C2=A0                                    Just wonder=
ing if anybody has ever thought about making a wind tuned ghost box. 
     =
My idea is to put a Theremin like charged antenna in a cardboard cylinder a=
bout 1 to 2 foot tall with a diameter of about 5 to 10 inches with a wind i=
nlet at the bottom and a screen at the top. The wind would blow a light pie=
ce of material around in the cylinder that would change the capacitance see=
n by the antenna. I was thinking you could probably hook the thing to an ol=
d non-electronically tuned radio directly across the tuning capacitor or in=
 place of it. At least thats what I would try first. It may need some sort =
of amplification and or filtering, don't know, just a hack electrician here=
. 
     It would be nice if the light piece of material was a ball of hair =
from a loved one but i would guess that a piece or more of aluminized mylar=
 would probably work better. And the  antenna should be offset to the side =
so the hairball could go up and down out of the field to choose whatever st=
ation the "others" would like.
 
         Heres a drawing:
     http://www.=
flickr.com/photos/johniestring/
 
 
      
                 
   
       
  =



----------MB_8CDA713B4C1FC48_C18_137F4_Webmail-m112.sysops.aol.com
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/html; charset="utf-8"


<div style=3D"font-family: arial; color: black; font-size: 10pt;"> A fan m=
ight work with this type of thing too, but it might make too much noise. I =
did get some fairly good files using a fan one hot summer, with the box, bu=
t the sound from the fan reached the mic, and it sounds like they are out i=
n a wind storm, but it did make them a bit louder. sf<br>
</div>

<div> <br=
>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div id=3D"ygrp-text">                     
<div>  Just wondering if a=
nybody has ever thought about making a wind tuned ghost box. <br>
     My i=
dea is to put a Theremin like charged antenna in a cardboard cylinder about=
 1 to 2 foot tall with a diameter of about 5 to 10 inches with a wind inlet=
 at the bottom and a screen at the top. The wind would blow a light piece o=
f material around in the cylinder that would change the capacitance seen by=
 the antenna. I was thinking you could probably hook the thing to an old no=
n-electronically tuned radio directly across the tuning capacitor or in pla=
ce of it. At least thats what I would try first. It may need some sort of a=
mplification and or filtering, don't know, just a hack electrician here. <b=
r>
     It would be nice if the light piece of material was a ball of hair =
from a loved one but i would guess that a piece or more of aluminized mylar=
 would probably work better. And the  antenna should be offset to the side =
so the hairball could go up and down out of the field to choose whatever st=
ation the "others" would like.<br>
 <br>
         Heres a drawing:<br>
    =
 <a target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.flickr.com/photos/johniestring/">h=
ttp://www.flickr.com/photos/johniestring/</a><br>
 <br>
 </div>
